Commutative Law
A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.
Subgroup generated by a set

For a group $G$ and a subset $X \subset G$, the subgroup $H$ generated by $X$ is defined as the intersection of all subgroups of $G$ containing $X$. It is the unique smallest subgroup of $G$ containing $X$ and consists of all elements of the form $x_{1}^{\varepsilon_{1}} \cdot \ldots \cdot x_{n}^{\varepsilon_{n}}$ where $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in X$ and $\varepsilon_{1}, \ldots, $\varepsilon_{n} \in \{1,-1\}$, with $n$ varying over $\mathbb{N}$.
Zero Ring
The zero ring is a ring where the unit element of addition (0) and the unit element of multiplication (1) are the same, i.e., 1=0. It consists of a single element 0.
Principal Ideal Domain
A ring $R$ is called a principal ideal domain if it is an integral domain and every ideal of $R$ is principal.
Prime Ideal
A proper ideal $\mathfrak{p} \subsetneq R$ in a ring $R$ is called a prime ideal if for elements $a, b \in R$, $ab \in \mathfrak{p}$ implies $a \in \mathfrak{p}$ or $b \in \mathfrak{p}$.
Finitely generated module
An A-module M is said to be finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators. It is also referred to as a finite A-module.
Torsion submodule
The torsion submodule T of an A-module M consists of all torsion elements of M. If T = 0, M is called torsion-free; if T = M, it is called a torsion module.
Algebraic Element

Given a field extension $K \subset L$, an element $\alpha \in L$ is called algebraic over $K$ if it satisfies an algebraic equation over $K$, i.e., an equation $\alpha^{n}+c_{1} \alpha^{n-1}+\ldots+c_{n}=0$ with coefficients $c_{1}, \ldots, c_{n} \in K$.
Splitting Field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield

A field $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ is a splitting field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ if the polynomial factorizes into linear factors in $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$. This implies that $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ contains all zeros of $X^q-X$.
Ideal corresponding to a subset
Given a subset \(U \subset \bar{K}^{n}\), the corresponding ideal \(I(U)\) in the polynomial ring \(K[X]\) consists of all polynomials that vanish on \(U\).
Dihedral Group

The dihedral group $D_{n}$, for $n \geq 3$, is the group of symmetries (rotations and reflections) of a regular (convex) $n$-gon. It is generated by the permutations $\sigma = (1, \ldots, n)$ and $\tau = \left(\begin{array}{ccccc}1 & 2 & 3 & \ldots & n \\ 1 & n & n-1 & \ldots & 2\end{array}\right)$.
Codomain
The codomain of a function is the set that contains all potential output values, even if some of those values are not actually produced by any input in the domain.
Inheritance_Analysis

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A Principal Ideal Domain (PID) is a ring where every ideal is principal. A Prime Ideal is a specific type of ideal within a ring, and in a PID, it is also principal. Thus, the concept of a Prime Ideal can be seen as a specialization of the concept of a Principal Ideal Domain, in the sense that a Prime Ideal is a particular kind of ideal that exists within the broader framework of ideals considered in a PID.
